response.answer_text: They are three ways to boost your sales: 1. Get more clients2. Sell more to existent clients3. Sell more often to your clients This is very general of course. If you in B2B sales like me, your first mission will be to get more clients. And this is how you do it: 1. WHAT PEOPLE ARE ACTUALLY BUYING?Like most people I used to think that people buy products and services. And as I found out it is simply not true!What people actually are buying is solutions to their problems! Problems create pain in human experience and as Zigmund Froid told us people are always trying to get away from PAIN and always will seek for PLEASURE. This is the way our brain works.  So the first mission of every sales rep is to understand what problems or pain they are experiencing, what bothers them, what they are not satisfied with, what cases them to wake up at night will cold sweat? And you find it by simply asking:"what is the challenge you are facing right now?", "What would you change or do differently in the current product?""If I could give you the ideal product, what features it will have?", "What you don`t want to see in your ideal product/service?" Stop selling products and sell solutions to people pain and problems. 2. PROSPECT LIKE A PRO!The second task will be find new clients by prospecting. They are many ways to do it. You can cold call, send emails, go door2door, use the social media and use referrals. Of course it is better to use a HOT leads, but if you are a new business or a new sales rep your only choice is the cold approach. Prospecting is the toughest part of selling and most sales people try to avoid it. Because you can be rejected, people will tell you terrible things about you and your product and so on. In order to be outstanding in prospecting you must develop "Unbeatable Mind" this is the biggest secret of every sales master. In order to thrive you must generate new prospects every day! In my experience you must speak between 10-15 decisions maker per day. If you do this every day, week, month and year you will be successful in selling. Getting new clients into your business is the number one priority. 3. CREATING RELATIONSHIPS. Their is a saying in sales: "you don`t close a deal you open a relationship".The number one skill in selling is to learn how to build relationships with people. People usually will buy from people that they know, like, trust and believe that they can help them. Here are ten commandments for building a relationship with people:1. Talk about what they want, and not what you want.2. Make them feel important-all man desire to feel this way.3. Don`t argue with people. No winners in arguments.4. Listen to people. It is a rare commodity today.5. Don`t critic people-every fool can do it, but wise man don`t6. Smile! It affects your tone of voice, people like happy people.7. Find something good in every person.8. Be grateful for the opportunity to to business with people,9. Price people. Don`t be sleasy, do it because you really believe in it.10. Be honest. No one likes lairs. 4. FIND THE GAP.The is the bridge between where people want to be and where are they now.Problems or pain this where they now.Solutions and pleasure-is where they want to be in the future.Your product-is the bridge that connects between the two. The bigger the gap between where people are and where they want to be the more valuable your product and the more valuable your product the price you can charge is higher.The gap is a measure of customer dissatisfaction.In order to find the gap you must ask questions: "What do you need in a solution?", What you would improve in your current product?" 5. BUILD VALUE. Value is what people are expecting to get out of a product or a service. What is the emotional satisfaction a man will get from using a product or service? Value is not a thing this is a process called valuing. The bigger problem a customer have and the more it is urgent the value of solving it goes up. If we have a desire or a need goes up the value of the solution or getting that desire also will go up. So CREATE VALUE!The equation to create money is: VALUE=MONEY.Selling is a process of exchanging value for money, and the bigger your value the more you will get paid. 6. OUTSTANDING CUSTOMER SERVICEWhat is more easy to do: to  recruit a new client or to sell to an exciting one?I know that you know the answer, of course to sell to the existing clients.In order to sell to your clients more and more frequently you must maintain an outstanding customer relationships. As I said in the begining sales is all about relationships. The more people trust you, the more they like you, the more they will buy from you. We all must focus how to create more trust in our relationships with our clients and create clients for life! Best regards!   So more clients

Targeting the right audience will be the single most important thing to boosting B2B sales. If you haven’t spent time dialing in your ICP (Ideal Client Profile), then you need to do so. Figure out what makes these people tick. What moves the needle for THEM? If you’re focusing too much on features; bells and whistles, then you are going to end up turning people away. They don’t care about what features your solution has, they care about how your features will help make their jobs easier, make them better, and help get them to where they want (and need) to go. Every time you ask for 15-20 minutes of someone’s time, it’s like withdrawing from your bank account. If you don’t have a relationship with that person, it’s like trying to withdraw $20 out of a bank account that has $0 in it. Even if you’re not educating someone on your solution, you can help them stay ahead of industry trends and provide other, actionable advice. And every time you do that, you’re adding a small deposit into that bank account. If you do this with someone, you’re adding $2 into that bank account. As time goes by, that balance grows and you can make your $20 withdrawal when the timing is right. But just having your ICP dialed in is not enough. In business, timing is everything. You must have a way to know which people, in your marketplace, are actively “shopping” for the solution you’re selling. Now, the timing is right. With person-level buying intent data, you will know exactly which people are shopping and researching for this type of solution. You’ll know when they’ve started researching YOUR company. Then, you’ll know the person’s name, how to contact them, where they work, and how far along their own buyer journey they are. (Disclaimer: I own this product, marketology.) Freakishly accurate, person-level buying intent data that eliminates the guesswork in marketing, outreach, and sales. You'll smash sales quotas, fill massive revenue gaps, and go to bed with a smile each night because you know you're only ever pursuing people who are actively shopping for your solution. Relentlessly pursuing peace of mind for our friends in the B2B tech world through identity resolution and person-level buying intent data. Making marketers smarter - 12Thirty1

Your B2B sales campaign is all about being able to attract prospects and keep them there. But winning customer loyalty is easier said than done when the majority of businesses are receiving over ten sales presentations every single day. You need to develop your B2B sales strategy so you can increase your conversion rates. Here are the best ways by which you can develop your B2B sales strategy and take advantage of an industry that’s growing by 14 percent per year:. 1. Use social media to know more about your competition. Social media is often used for researching customers. B2B companies especially should use this tool to find out more about their competition. The leading social media network for B2B companies is LinkedIn. It's quickly become a hub for professionals in this industry. Follow the major influencers in your niche to learn what they're doing. The more data you can gather, the better. You don’t necessarily have to copy what others are doing, but you can quickly find out what is and isn't working for them. 2. Learn to differentiate yourself from the competition. The key to long-term success in B2B sales is to constantly differentiate yourself from the competition. Naturally, this is easier said than done. The moment you find something unique, the clock starts ticking down. It won’t be long before someone else copies your idea. But differentiation should still be at the top of your priorities list. You should always stay one and two steps ahead of your competitors. Leveraging the unique elements you have will help you to stand out from your leads' perspective. 3. Stop cold-calling, start researching. Everything in the world of sales revolves around data. One area where data comes in handy is in figuring out how likely a business is to respond to you in a positive way. The reality is that cold-calling is no longer the best use of your time. Less than 5 percent of cold calls will lead to anything. Researching your prospects in advance will make it easy to establish a relationship and to figure out where your offering fits in with your prospect's business model. The majority of businesses have no time for cold calls. They’ll quickly cut you off because they don’t want to have to waste their time explaining their company to you. Yes, researching takes time. You’ll have no choice but to reduce the number of leads you’re getting in contact with. But you’ll be increasing your chances of converting those leads. Related: Don't Wage a Price War. Win Sales by Eliminating Your Competition. 4. Cut to the chase. The B2B sales cycle should contain as few steps as possible. Your prospects don’t want to listen to the long speeches and sales fluff you come up with. They want to know how you’re going to solve a problem for them. They want to know how your solution is going to directly or indirectly make them more money. Show respect for the time your lead has. Think about an elevator pitch approach and how you can pitch your solution in that same amount of your time. Your solution should be easily explained in less than a minute. Create a strong value proposition and let your prospect decide if it’s worth it. Improve on your long-term ideas. So many companies are obsessed with closing the sale right now. This is short-term thinking. B2B companies will live or die based on the number of customers who stick with them through thick and thin. The best B2B companies are concerned with closing the sale, but more so with building their own reputations. That’s what convinces other people to approach them and then come back for more. So, think about how you’re going to build your reputation. Have a long-term plan, which will include getting back to people after they’ve bought into your unique selling proposition. As the relationship advances, have a strategy for how you’re going to upsell.

You can boost your B2B Sales by focusing on Back End...keep on reading... Many times I have seen companies/individuals are always running after new leads and not fully capitalizing existing clients. It's 15X harder to make the first sale to someone than it is to make the second sale to them. This means... The significant revenue is in the Back End... Not the Front End. Think - HubSpot, Netflix, Dollar Shave Club, etc. Without a back end offer and strategy, it's easy to get anxious about future sales. Knowing this... When I get a new client... I believe the real work has just begun. If I can sell one new solution/license in their company... I can sell multiple over two years period. (this is where the real money is made) Just by doing these two things every month, your sales will multiply: 1 - Call existing customers and do 10 minutes check-in 2 - Incubate new/back end sales opportunities Don't have a back end product? No problem... Your customers are your single best source of new product ideas, which can turn into easy-to-sell, high margin, back end sales opportunities.

Make sure you are using a strong CRM program, with an integrated follow up system and that you are utilizing it efficiently. Create and keep updated profiles on all of your existing, as well as, any new potential clients that you have and add to your funnel; make sure to take the time to add each call/email/visit/interaction you have and to add personal notes (what's important to them, interests they have, kids, family, hobbies, things you have in common etc) so you have to reference when following up in the future. These are key to keep a full and constant flowing pipeline. Keeping a solid follow-up system in place is critical to maximize the earning potential for each client/account. Even after a sale, especially after a sale it's important to follow up with your clients to make sure that everything is going good and they don't need any further assistance and/or need for additional services you may offer/sell; if you did your job right and built trust and rapport with them, then they are your best resource for additional clients and business to fill your pipeline! A high percentage of my new business comes directly or indirectly from my existing customer base, in the form of referrals and repeat business; what's even better is that it's free marketing/advertising AND coming referred from a mutual source lowers a lot of the initial barriers and makes for a much easier, more smooth and usually much faster sale. Networking, exceptional customer service (going the extra mile and following through with what you promise) and follow up are all very critical in business to business sales. One more thing…ask for the sale! So many consultants present and pitch the product/service, but fail to actually ask for the sale and/or attempt to get a commitment! …Best of luck

Here are the key steps to follow and learn how to boost my sales if your are into B2B sales!  1) Be prepared for an open-ended conversation — You need to understand every prospect is different, having unique values and thought processes. Do not limit yourself and be prepared for an open-ended conversation with your prospective clients. 2) Talk to the decision-maker — If you do not want to waste your time convincing one person after another having countless conversations to close one deal, make sure that you talk to the decision-maker. If you are unable to connect to them directly, use referrals, or mutual people to reach them. 3) Choose outcomes that benefit both — While negotiating with your prospect, try to reach an outcome that is a win-win for both the sides. It will show your respect and willingness to work with them again in the future and build long term relationships with your clients. 4) Follow up extensively — Do not hesitate in reaching out to your prospects after they have given a yellow signal. Try to fix a particular time when you can connect to them for a follow-up and keep doing that until you get a definite answer. 5) Build trust — When you have just started your business, you must build trust with your clients and prospects. It is the only way that your business can sustain in the long run. There are many ways in which you can build trust, like having a friendly conversation with your client rather than a formal one, being honest with them, actively listening to their problems, and being empathetic to them. 6) Prepare short demos — Try to give short and simplified demos to your prospects. Overloading them with irrelevant information would not be a good choice. Provide only that information which is necessary and what your prospect would be able to retain. 7) Prioritize customer satisfaction — Remember, if your customers are happy and satisfied, they will come to you again and again. It will build a good reputation in the market, which is essential for any start-up. You can ensure that your customers are satisfied by providing them with after-sales services, taking feedback after regular intervals, and making your reach out process easy. 8) Target small businesses — Targeting small businesses would be good for a head start. They would be easy to convince as you, being a start-up, would be able to relate to their problems and identify their pain points easily. 9) Make the perfect sales pitch — Before you make your pitch to the prospect, spend some time researching their needs, values, and pain points. This will help you prepare an effective sales pitch and close the deal comfortably. Do not spend too much time on exaggerating the benefits of your product or your company. Focus more on grabbing the interest and understanding the needs of your prospect. 10) Use online methods for marketing — Whether you want to find leads or attract prospects, all your problems have one way out, go online. You can use LinkedIn to generate quality leads, use different social media platforms to promote your business, or start writing blogs to attract more prospects. All the best, thanks!

Before thinking about a vertical sales trajectory, I’d recommend strengthening lead generation efforts and targeting those prospects that are most likely going to benefit from your product/service. Identifying your Target Audience is a great way to understand what lead generation method will work for you. Connect with key employees so that time isn’t wasted selling your product to those who aren’t even responsible for making the final decisions. Understand which mediums the target audience frequent and the type of CTA’s that work well on them so can narrow down on the best methods to generate leads. Some of the most well-known methods generate leads are: Content Marketing: The creation and sharing of online material intended to stimulate interest in a brand or service is called ‘Content Marketing’. Publishing EBooks, white papers, guidelines, infographics, case studies and any other information relevant to your target audience and giving it away for free can greatly aid a lead generation exercise. Use Call-to-Action ads to draw consumers towards exclusive (free) information in exchange for an email address. For example, creating an EBook called “The future of B2B Lead Generation” will get attention and adding CTA such as “Get it free only for today!” pushes the person to download the book and creates an opportunity to get their contact details. On getting their contact details, a service such as Replyup will set up a sequence of follow-up emails to routinely remind them of the product and stay relevant in the mind of the consumer. If your content is informative, entertaining and sociable it becomes the perfect tool to capture interest in the brand as it satisfies the main motive behind why people use the Internet. Free Content attracts people easily, and they start assuming your expertise when they benefit from the content. Soon people will feel free to socialize with you as their comfort level increases (especially on platforms such as Quora). This way the content isn’t impersonal and starts having a more human touch. Social Media: Use different social media channels to promote your brand through a great content strategy, which uses a mix of well-researched articles, eye-catching videos, and statistically rich infographics. LinkedIn is a great tool for prospecting and its potential as a lead generation tool should be harnessed by connecting with the large network of professionals it hosts on the platform. LinkedIn Groups are important for visibility and can be used to engage in conversations with key employees of companies you want to target. On joining a group, it sends email updates about the topics being discussed and unlocks opportunities to become a part of the discussion. Conducting Paid Search Campaigns: Use the vast network of Google to conduct a Google AdWords campaign. Adverts can be posted in the following ways through the AdWords system. 1. The Display Network – Adverts that appear on various websites that have agreed to allow Google to serve adverts to its visitors. Cross-referencing this with your target audience to be more specific about what sites the adverts appear on. 2. The Search Network - These adverts are situated at the top of the search engine results pages. 3. YouTube adverts – These are very effective in increasing brand exposure, but not so good for generating new leads. Re-marketing is a process in which Adverts are displayed to people that have already visited your website making them extremely targeted. This helps in brand recognition and reinforces your brand's presences in the audience’s mind. Establishing a target cost per sale is crucial with AdWords. It is a bidding war so you can find yourself constantly bidding higher and higher so it’s important to understand the associated click statistics. Networking: Start networking at Trade Shows and business related events. Many of these are not great but if you know the decision makers of your target clients will be attending then why not try and get some face-to-face time with them? Target events where decision makers relevant to your business will be attending. Find opportunities to speak at events to demonstrate your knowledge. Search Engine Optimization: Put effort into SEO. Tools such as Moz, SEMRush, Ahrefs and Raven can help you gain good organic rankings. However, SEO can take some time to achieve any real exciting results. Hard work and patience is the key to reaping rewards from this activity. Use Google Analytics to monitor how your traffic levels are doing. Using a combination of competitive and long tail keywords, you can increase your website traffic as well as increase conversions on your website. Lead Generation Companies: If this seems too daunting and you want to focus on selling your product rather than nurturing leads, I’d suggest hiring a Lead Generation company to do the groundwork for you. It’s an efficient way of generating leads and can make the selling process more efficient for you and your sales team. I have recently worked with a couple of companies and conclude that Ripple is one of the best. They’re an all-around service that is a prospecting, outreach, and email management tool altogether and have an easy to use interface. Even though they are a fairly new company, I’m impressed with their work. It's also important to remember that in B2B the pace is comparatively slower than B2C, so don’t try to rush leads into sealing a deal or you might lose them completely. At the same time keep an eye out for competitors and their strategies to stay ahead of the curve.

My top tips for AEs: Grab your CEO and bring her into bigger deals. Ask your CEO to join you on a few sales calls a month. Deals will close at a higher rate if the CEO joins. Customers love to talk to the CEO. Even the CEO of a 4 person startup.Slow it down and hyper-personalize your emails and communication. Don’t misuse tools like Mixmax and Salesloft and Outreach. Slow down, research the customer, get to know their needs, and who they are. Tell them how your product truly will solve their problem. Watch your hit rate go up.Pitch >all< the stakeholders. Take the time to do a personalized demo and pitch for everyone that might use your product. Make the time.Start a weekly webinar for your (or ideally, all) prospects. If the company isn’t doing one, you just do it. Invite all your prospects each week. This is a great way for them to continue to engage, even if they don’t want to do a traditional sales call this week. More here: Webinars Almost Always Work | SaaStrListen to each others’ calls. Get Gong or Chorus or whatever and listen to the calls of the top closers.Deeply, truly understand the product. Know every feature, every use case. That’s who customers really want to talk to. And why they sometimes buy from one vendor over another. Study up here.Work harder. This isn’t as trite as it sounds. Are you really working as efficiently as you can? As hard as you can? Are you wasting a lot of time? The best reps really do get more done with each hour.Treat each prospect like a king or queen. Especially the smaller ones. Don’t talk down to smaller customers or deals. Every customer cares about their business, small or large. Treat even the smallest customers with the same respect as the big ones, and watch your close rates go way, way up here.Always add value with each email, call, Zoom, etc. Are you sure that email you are about to send adds new value? Make every interaction count. Make sure each one adds value. If it doesn’t, slow it down and figure out how to add value.Be hyper-responsive. No one wants to wait 24 hours for a sales rep to call them back. No one. Email or call them back within 90 seconds. Watch your close rates go up. Especially, when the competition doesn’t.Help your customers more after the deal closes. You’ll be tempted to move on to the next deal. But if you keep helping after, that dramatically increases the odds they refer you to other potential customers.

Take a look at the current workflow and find where the biggest time suck is - typically we've seen it with getting initial meetings book and ongoing follow up with current opportunities. Then find ways to improve those areas. For example - we notified a large amount of time was spent trying to book demos with our inbound leads. So we built an option into the Drift – Messaging For Marketing & Sales live chat to enable sending calendars. Quickly cuts out the ~5 emails it takes to book a meeting. Another area to look at is what things do sales reps skip that are part of the current process. Sales naturally does the least amount of work necessary to make the most money - so they are skipping for a reason. How can those steps be improved, so they are a value add and not just a time suck.

The biggest bottleneck in a sales workflow is anything that has to be done manually. For example, if you’re manually writing an email that could be templated because you send it a lot or send it to lots of people, you’re wasting time. To improve your B2B sales workflow, you need to find ways of automating repetitive tasks. Some things obviously can’t be automated, like demo calls. However, other things can be automated with the right tools. For example, you can automate your high volume prospecting emails with a tool like SalesLoft. Automate one-to-one emails using templates and a tool like Yesware. Lead research and tracking can be automated with a tool like RocketBolt. Even call scheduling can be automated thanks to X.ai. Basically, the more you can remove direct human interaction in your sales pipeline, the more efficient you’ll be.
